column4: Most commonly caused by stroke in left middle cerebral artery territory (inferior division); can also result from tumor, trauma, or other focal brain lesions affecting left temporal lobe
column5: Fluent, effortless speech with normal prosody but poor content; word salad, paraphasias (semantic and phonemic), neologisms; severely impaired auditory comprehension; impaired repetition; impaired naming; patient often unaware of deficit (anosognosia); may have right visual field defect
column6: Acute onset with stroke; may improve over weeks to months with rehabilitation; comprehension typically recovers better than fluent output
column7: Broca aphasia, global aphasia, transcortical sensory aphasia, delirium, acute psychosis, metabolic encephalopathy
column8: Clinical diagnosis based on language examination showing fluent speech with impaired comprehension; brain imaging (CT or MRI) showing lesion in left superior temporal gyrus and surrounding areas; formal speech-language pathology evaluation
column9: Speech and language therapy; treat underlying cause (stroke, tumor, etc.); supportive care; address behavioral issues if present

column2: Quadriplegia and anarthria with preserved consciousness and vertical eye movements; patient can only communicate by blinking or moving eyes vertically; ventral pontine lesion
column3: Bilateral ventral pontine lesion disrupting corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts while sparing reticular activating system and vertical gaze centers in midbrain; most commonly from basilar artery thrombosis or pontine hemorrhage
column4: Rare; most commonly caused by basilar artery thrombosis (60% of cases); also pontine hemorrhage, central pontine myelinolysis, trauma, tumor; can occur at any age but more common in adults with vascular risk factors
column5: Quadriplegia, anarthria (inability to speak), preserved consciousness and cognition, preserved vertical eye movements and blinking, loss of horizontal eye movements, inability to move face or limbs; patient fully aware but cannot move or speak
column6: Acute onset with stroke or hemorrhage; chronic condition if patient survives; some recovery of motor function possible over months to years but most remain severely disabled
column7: Coma, persistent vegetative state, akinetic mutism, severe Guillain-Barre syndrome, brainstem encephalitis, neuromuscular junction disorders
column8: Clinical diagnosis based on examination showing quadriplegia and anarthria with preserved consciousness (demonstrated by ability to follow commands with vertical eye movements or blinking); MRI showing bilateral ventral pontine lesion; electroencephalogram showing normal awake patterns
column9: Supportive care; mechanical ventilation if needed; communication devices using eye movements or blinking; physical and occupational therapy; treat underlying cause (anticoagulation or thrombolysis for basilar thrombosis if within time window); prevent complications (deep vein thrombosis, pressure ulcers, aspiration pneumonia)

column2: Bilateral temporal lobe damage (often herpes encephalitis) causing hyperphagia, hypersexuality, hyperorality (examining objects by mouth), visual agnosia, placidity, and hypermetamorphosis (compulsive exploration)
column3: Bilateral damage to amygdala and anterior temporal lobes disrupts limbic system function; results in loss of fear response, inability to recognize objects visually, and disinhibited oral and sexual behaviors
column4: Rare; most commonly caused by herpes simplex encephalitis affecting bilateral temporal lobes; also bilateral temporal infarction, trauma, Pick disease, Alzheimer disease, anoxic brain injury; more common in children after encephalitis
column5: Hyperorality (90% of cases), hypersexuality (82%), placidity (loss of fear and emotional responses), visual agnosia (inability to recognize objects visually despite intact vision), hyperphagia, hypermetamorphosis (compulsive touching and exploration), amnesia, epilepsy (70%)
column6: Acute or subacute onset depending on cause; chronic condition; partial recovery possible over months to years but most patients have persistent deficits; residual disabilities vary from major to fairly mild
column7: Frontotemporal dementia, Alzheimer disease, delirium, mania, psychosis, metabolic encephalopathy, other causes of behavioral changes
column8: Clinical diagnosis based on characteristic behavioral syndrome; brain MRI showing bilateral temporal lobe lesions; herpes simplex virus polymerase chain reaction in cerebrospinal fluid if encephalitis suspected; neuropsychological testing
column9: Treat underlying cause (acyclovir for herpes encephalitis); symptomatic treatment with carbamazepine, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, or neuroleptics with variable control; corticosteroids or immunosuppressive agents (rituximab) for some etiologies; behavioral therapy and supportive care

column2: Hypotonic polyuria (greater than 3 liters per day) with compensatory polydipsia and nocturia; hypernatremia if inadequate water access; loss of posterior pituitary bright spot on MRI
column3: Loss or impaired function of vasopressinergic neurons in hypothalamus or posterior pituitary causing deficiency of arginine vasopressin; inability to concentrate urine leads to excessive renal water losses
column4: Caused by neoplastic (craniopharyngioma, germinoma, metastases), traumatic (neurosurgery, head injury), autoimmune (lymphocytic hypophysitis), or idiopathic destruction of vasopressin-synthesizing neurons; can occur at any age
column5: Polyuria (5 to 6 liters per day or more), polydipsia with preference for cold water, nocturia (3 or more events per night), drinking at night; hypernatremia if inadequate water access; symptoms may have sudden onset; may have anterior pituitary deficiencies if underlying lesion present
column6: Acute onset with trauma or surgery; subacute with tumors or infiltrative disease; chronic condition requiring lifelong treatment; triphasic response after pituitary surgery (initial diabetes insipidus, then antidiuresis, then permanent diabetes insipidus)
column7: Primary polydipsia, nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, osmotic diuresis (diabetes mellitus, hypercalcemia), diuretic use
column8: Low urine osmolality (less than 300 mOsm per kg) with high or high-normal plasma osmolality (greater than 287 mOsm per kg); hypernatremia; water deprivation test showing inability to concentrate urine with response to desmopressin; copeptin assay (low copeptin diagnostic); MRI showing loss of posterior pituitary bright spot, pituitary stalk thickening, or mass lesion
column9: Desmopressin (synthetic vasopressin analog) orally, intranasally, or subcutaneously; ensure adequate water access; treat underlying cause; monitor sodium levels to avoid hyponatremia from overtreatment; hormone replacement for anterior pituitary deficiencies if present

column2: Euvolemic hyponatremia with concentrated urine in patient with small cell lung cancer
column3: Nonosmotic release of ADH leads to water retention by kidneys, causing dilutional hyponatremia and water excess
column4: Most common cause of hyponatremia; causes include malignancy (24%), drugs (18%), pulmonary conditions (11%), CNS disorders (9%)
column5: Weakness, headache, confusion; severe cases: seizures, coma; euvolemic on exam
column6: Variable; depends on rapidity of sodium decline
column7: Adrenal insufficiency, severe hypothyroidism, psychogenic polydipsia, cerebral salt wasting
column8: Euvolemic hypotonic hyponatremia, urine osmolality greater than 100 mOsm per kg, urine sodium greater than 30 mEq per L; rule out thyroid and adrenal dysfunction
column9: Fluid restriction; 3% saline for severe symptomatic cases; treat underlying cause; second-line: salt tablets with furosemide, urea, tolvaptan

column2: Child with headache, visual field defects, growth failure, and calcified sellar mass on imaging
column3: Rare embryonic malformation from Rathke pouch remnants; adamantinomatous type (CTNNB1 mutation) is cystic with calcifications; papillary type (BRAF V600E mutation) is solid
column4: Bimodal age distribution: 5-15 years and 45-60 years for adamantinomatous; papillary restricted to adults; 1-3% of intracranial tumors in adults, 5-10% in children
column5: Headache, visual impairment, endocrine deficiencies (growth hormone deficiency most common), nausea, vomiting, hypothalamic obesity
column6: Slow-growing; insidious onset of symptoms
column7: Pituitary adenoma, Rathke cleft cyst, meningioma, germ cell tumor, optic glioma
column8: MRI (preferred); CT shows calcifications in 90%; endocrine evaluation for hypopituitarism; visual field testing
column9: Hypothalamus-sparing surgery followed by radiotherapy for residual tumor; BRAF/MEK inhibitors for papillary type with BRAF V600E mutation

column2: Bitemporal hemianopsia from macroadenoma compressing optic chiasm; galactorrhea and amenorrhea from prolactinoma
column3: Monoclonal neoplasms of adenohypophyseal cells; functioning tumors secrete hormones autonomously; nonfunctioning tumors cause mass effect
column4: Prevalence 1 in 1100 clinically evident; 53% prolactinomas, 30% nonfunctioning, 12% somatotropinomas, 4% corticotropinomas
column5: Mass effect: headache, visual field defects, hypopituitarism; hormone excess: prolactinoma (galactorrhea, hypogonadism), acromegaly (enlarged hands/feet), Cushing disease (obesity, hypertension)
column6: Chronic; gradual onset
column7: Craniopharyngioma, meningioma, Rathke cleft cyst, hypophysitis, metastases
column8: MRI with dedicated pituitary protocol; endocrine evaluation for hormone hypersecretion and hypopituitarism; visual field testing for macroadenomas
column9: Prolactinomas: dopamine agonists (cabergoline, bromocriptine); others: transsphenoidal surgery first-line; medical therapy for residual disease; radiotherapy for refractory cases

column2: Young adult with auditory hallucinations, paranoid delusions, social withdrawal, and disorganized speech
column3: Cortical excitatory-inhibitory imbalance and dopaminergic dysfunction; multifactorial etiology including genetic predisposition, neurodevelopmental factors, environmental stressors
column4: Lifetime prevalence approximately 1%; onset typically late adolescence to early adulthood; no gender predilection
column5: Positive symptoms: hallucinations, delusions, disorganized speech; negative symptoms: blunted affect, avolition, asociality; cognitive deficits: impaired working memory, executive function
column6: Prodromal phase for years; requires 6 months of continuous signs with 1 month of active symptoms
column7: Schizoaffective disorder, bipolar disorder with psychosis, major depression with psychosis, substance-induced psychosis, medical causes (autoimmune encephalitis, brain tumor)
column8: Clinical diagnosis per DSM-5 criteria; rule out medical causes (thyroid, metabolic, toxicology); neuroimaging to exclude structural lesions
column9: Antipsychotics (dopamine D2 receptor antagonists); psychosocial interventions (cognitive behavioral therapy, psychoeducation, cognitive remediation); long-term maintenance therapy

column2: Thunderclap headache with subarachnoid hemorrhage; berry-like aneurysm at circle of Willis bifurcation
column3: Berry-like dilations at arterial bifurcations from degeneration of internal elastic lamina, endothelial dysfunction, hemodynamic stress, and inflammation
column4: Prevalence 3.2% in general population; higher in women, age greater than 30 years, family history, hypertension, polycystic kidney disease
column5: Unruptured: often asymptomatic or mass effect (cranial nerve palsy); ruptured: thunderclap headache, meningismus, altered consciousness, focal deficits
column6: Unruptured: variable growth over years; ruptured: sudden onset
column7: Ruptured: other causes of subarachnoid hemorrhage (arteriovenous malformation, trauma); unruptured: other intracranial masses
column8: CT angiography or MR angiography for detection; digital subtraction angiography for treatment planning
column9: Unruptured: conservative management (smoking cessation, blood pressure control, imaging surveillance) for small (less than 7 mm) aneurysms; endovascular coiling or surgical clipping for high-risk aneurysms

column2: Preterm infant born at 26 weeks with sudden drop in hematocrit and bulging fontanelle on day 2 of life
column3: Bleeding from fragile germinal matrix capillaries due to impaired cerebral autoregulation, hemodynamic instability, and ischemia-reperfusion injury in preterm brain
column4: Affects 25% of very low birth weight infants (less than 1500 g); incidence increases with decreasing gestational age; 48% occur in first 6 hours of life
column5: Often clinically silent; severe cases: altered consciousness, bulging fontanelle, seizures, apnea, hypotension, drop in hematocrit
column6: Onset typically 24-48 hours after birth; 10% within 12 hours; can progress to post-hemorrhagic hydrocephalus
column7: Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy, stroke, infection, metabolic disorders, coagulopathy
column8: Cranial ultrasound (preferred screening); graded 1-4 based on extent of bleeding; serial imaging to monitor progression
column9: Supportive care; prevention with antenatal steroids; management of post-hemorrhagic ventricular dilatation ranges from observation to ventriculoperitoneal shunt

column2: Young adult with drug overdose or hypoglycemia presenting with depressed consciousness but preserved brainstem reflexes and symmetric motor responses
column3: Diffuse neuronal dysfunction from systemic metabolic derangements affecting cerebral cortex bilaterally; disrupts neuronal metabolism and neurotransmission without structural brain injury
column4: Accounts for 72% of coma cases in emergency department; more common in younger patients
column5: Depressed consciousness, normal or low blood pressure, symmetric motor responses, preserved pupillary light reflexes, absence of focal neurological signs
column6: Variable; can be rapid onset (minutes to hours) with potential for quick reversal if treated promptly
column7: Structural coma, psychogenic unresponsiveness, sedation, postictal state
column8: Serum glucose, electrolytes, renal and liver function, thyroid function, ammonia, arterial blood gas, toxicology screen, complete blood count; neuroimaging to exclude structural lesions
column9: Treat underlying cause: glucose for hypoglycemia, thiamine for Wernicke encephalopathy, naloxone for opioid overdose, hemodialysis for severe metabolic acidosis or toxins; supportive care with airway protection

column2: Patient with bilateral thalamic stroke or severe traumatic brain injury presenting with hypersomnolence and small reactive pupils
column3: Injury to thalamus or hypothalamus disrupts arousal pathways; thalamus serves as relay station between ascending reticular activating system and cortex
column4: Uncommon; can result from artery of Percheron stroke (bilateral paramedian thalamic infarction), severe traumatic brain injury, or deep midline tumors
column5: Hypersomnolence, small but reactive pupils, intact oculocephalic reflexes, vertical gaze abnormalities, memory impairment when aroused, temperature dysregulation
column6: Onset depends on etiology; stroke is acute, tumors are gradual
column7: Metabolic coma, pontine hemorrhage, drug intoxication, psychiatric disorder
column8: MRI brain (more sensitive than CT for thalamic lesions), CT if hemorrhage suspected, metabolic workup to exclude systemic causes
column9: Treat underlying cause: thrombolysis or thrombectomy for acute ischemic stroke, surgical decompression for mass lesions, supportive care; stimulant medications (amantadine, modafinil) may aid arousal

column2: Patient with basilar artery thrombosis or pontine hemorrhage presenting with sudden coma, pinpoint pupils, and absent horizontal eye movements
column3: Direct injury to brainstem ascending reticular activating system in pons or midbrain; disrupts arousal pathways at their origin
column4: Represents minority of coma cases; causes include brainstem stroke, hemorrhage, tumor, or cerebellar mass with brainstem compression
column5: Sudden onset coma, abnormal pupillary responses (pinpoint or mid-position fixed pupils), impaired or absent oculocephalic and oculovestibular reflexes, abnormal breathing patterns, extensor or flexor posturing
column6: Acute onset (minutes to hours) for vascular causes; gradual for tumors
column7: Metabolic coma, supratentorial mass with herniation, drug intoxication (opioids cause pinpoint pupils but preserved reflexes)
column8: CT or MRI brain to identify brainstem lesion or posterior fossa mass; CT angiography if vascular occlusion suspected; metabolic workup
column9: Treat underlying cause: thrombolysis or thrombectomy for basilar artery occlusion, surgical decompression for cerebellar hemorrhage or mass, external ventricular drain for obstructive hydrocephalus; supportive care with airway protection

column2: Patient with large hemispheric stroke or subdural hematoma presenting with progressive decline in consciousness, asymmetric motor responses, and signs of herniation
column3: Unilateral or bilateral hemispheric lesion causes mass effect with lateral tissue displacement and herniation; compression of brainstem or bilateral cortical dysfunction impairs consciousness
column4: Common cause of structural coma; etiologies include intracerebral hemorrhage, subdural or epidural hematoma, large ischemic stroke, tumor, abscess
column5: Progressive decline in consciousness, focal neurological signs (hemiparesis, aphasia), asymmetric pupils (dilated ipsilateral pupil with herniation), abnormal motor responses, Cushing triad with increased intracranial pressure
column6: Progressive over hours to days depending on rate of mass expansion; acute hemorrhage progresses faster than tumor
column7: Metabolic coma, subtentorial lesion, meningitis, seizure with postictal state
column8: CT brain (first-line for hemorrhage and mass effect), MRI for ischemic stroke and subtle lesions; assess for midline shift and herniation
column9: Treat underlying cause: surgical evacuation of hematoma, decompressive craniectomy for malignant edema, osmotic therapy (mannitol or hypertonic saline) for elevated intracranial pressure, external ventricular drain for hydrocephalus; supportive care

column2: Patient with psychiatric history presenting with apparent unresponsiveness but normal neurological examination, resistance to eye opening, and inconsistent responses
column3: Conversion disorder or malingering; no organic brain dysfunction; diagnosis of exclusion after thorough medical and neurological evaluation
column4: Rare; more common in patients with known psychiatric disorders or secondary gain
column5: Apparent unresponsiveness with resistance to passive eye opening, normal pupillary and brainstem reflexes, inconsistent motor responses, avoidance of hand drop onto face, normal vital signs
column6: Variable; may fluctuate with observation
column7: Metabolic coma, structural brain lesions (especially bilateral thalamic stroke), nonconvulsive status epilepticus, locked-in syndrome, catatonia
column8: Diagnosis of exclusion: normal neuroimaging, normal electroencephalogram, normal metabolic workup; electroencephalogram shows normal awake patterns; consider video electroencephalogram monitoring
column9: Psychiatric evaluation and treatment; avoid unnecessary invasive procedures; reassurance and supportive care; treat underlying psychiatric condition

column2: Young adult with week-long episode of decreased need for sleep, grandiosity, pressured speech, and risky behavior requiring hospitalization
column3: Dysregulation of mood circuits involving prefrontal cortex, amygdala, and striatum; altered monoaminergic neurotransmission; genetic and environmental factors contribute
column4: Lifetime prevalence 0.6 to 1.0%; equal in males and females; median age of onset 20 years; over 70% manifest before age 25
column5: Manic episodes: elevated or irritable mood, decreased need for sleep, grandiosity, racing thoughts, increased goal-directed activity, impulsivity, risk-taking; may have depressive episodes; psychotic symptoms in up to 75% of manic episodes
column6: Manic episodes last at least 7 days or require hospitalization; depressive episodes last at least 2 weeks; episodes separated by periods of remission or cycling
column7: Bipolar II disorder, substance-induced bipolar disorder, bipolar disorder due to medical condition, schizoaffective disorder, major depressive disorder, borderline personality disorder, attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder
column8: Clinical diagnosis based on history and mental status examination; rule out medical causes (thyroid disease, neurological conditions); toxicology screen; collateral history from family helpful
column9: Acute mania: mood stabilizers (lithium, valproate), atypical antipsychotics (quetiapine, olanzapine, aripiprazole); maintenance: lithium (most effective overall), valproate, atypical antipsychotics; psychotherapy (psychoeducation, cognitive behavioral therapy)

column2: Patient with recurrent major depressive episodes and at least one 4-day period of elevated mood and increased energy that did not require hospitalization
column3: Similar pathophysiology to Bipolar I disorder; dysregulation of mood circuits and neurotransmitter systems; genetic vulnerability with environmental triggers
column4: Lifetime prevalence 0.4 to 1.1%; more common in females; depressive episodes outnumber hypomanic episodes by ratio of 39 to 1
column5: Hypomanic episodes: elevated or irritable mood, increased energy, decreased need for sleep lasting at least 4 days; major depressive episodes: depressed mood, anhedonia, neurovegetative symptoms; no history of mania
column6: Hypomanic episodes last at least 4 days; depressive episodes last at least 2 weeks; chronic course with frequent recurrences
column7: Major depressive disorder, Bipolar I disorder, cyclothymic disorder, borderline personality disorder, substance-induced mood disorder, persistent depressive disorder
column8: Clinical diagnosis; careful history to identify hypomanic episodes (often missed); collateral information crucial; rule out medical and substance-induced causes
column9: Acute depression: mood stabilizers, atypical antipsychotics; avoid antidepressant monotherapy; maintenance: mood stabilizers (lithium, lamotrigine), atypical antipsychotics; psychotherapy (cognitive behavioral therapy, interpersonal and social rhythm therapy)

column2: Patient with 2 weeks of depressed mood, anhedonia, insomnia, poor concentration, and feelings of worthlessness without history of mania or hypomania
column3: Dysfunction of monoaminergic neurotransmitters (serotonin, norepinephrine, dopamine); impaired neuroplasticity; dysregulation of hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis; genetic and environmental factors
column4: Lifetime risk approaches 30%; twice as common in women; bimodal onset (twenties and fifties)
column5: Depressed mood or anhedonia plus at least 4 additional symptoms: sleep disturbance, appetite or weight change, psychomotor changes, fatigue, worthlessness or guilt, poor concentration, suicidal ideation
column6: Episode lasts at least 2 weeks; can be single episode or recurrent; chronic if lasts over 2 years
column7: Bipolar disorder (I or II), persistent depressive disorder, adjustment disorder, substance-induced depressive disorder, depressive disorder due to medical condition, grief, normal sadness
column8: Clinical diagnosis; screen for bipolar disorder (ask about manic or hypomanic symptoms); rule out medical causes (thyroid disease, anemia); assess suicide risk
column9: First-line: selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors or serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors; psychotherapy (cognitive behavioral therapy, interpersonal therapy); combination therapy for moderate to severe; electroconvulsive therapy for severe or treatment-resistant cases

column1: Major Depressive Disorder with Psychotic Features
column2: Elderly patient with severe depression, delusions of guilt or poverty, psychomotor retardation
column3: Severe depression with hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis hyperactivity; mood-congruent delusions involve themes of guilt, disease, death, nihilism, deserved punishment
column4: Approximately 10-11% of major depressive disorder patients; higher suicide risk and treatment resistance than nonpsychotic depression
column5: Depressed mood, anhedonia, delusions or hallucinations, psychomotor disturbances, severe guilt, melancholic features
column6: At least 2 weeks of depressive symptoms with psychotic features present during episode
column7: Schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, bipolar disorder with psychotic features, delirium, substance-induced psychotic disorder, psychotic disorder due to medical condition
column8: Clinical interview using DSM-5 criteria; rule out medical causes and substance use; assess for mood-congruent versus mood-incongruent psychotic features
column9: Combination of antidepressant plus antipsychotic is first-line; electroconvulsive therapy is particularly effective and may be preferred

column2: Young adult with chronic mood swings that never quite meet criteria for full manic or depressive episodes
column3: Temperamental predisposition to mood instability; may represent subsyndromal bipolar spectrum disorder
column4: Onset typically in adolescence or early adulthood; 15-50% risk of progression to bipolar I or II disorder
column5: Numerous periods of hypomanic symptoms and depressive symptoms that do not meet full episode criteria; symptoms present more days than not
column6: At least 2 years in adults or 1 year in children/adolescents; symptom-free intervals no longer than 2 months
column7: Bipolar I disorder, bipolar II disorder, borderline personality disorder, substance-induced mood disorder, hyperthyroidism
column8: Clinical interview and longitudinal history; daily mood charting helpful; rule out substance use and medical causes
column9: Mood stabilizers such as lithium or valproate; psychotherapy for coping strategies; close monitoring for conversion to bipolar disorder

column2: Patient who says "I have always been this way" with chronic low-grade depression for years
column3: Chronic depressive symptoms that become part of day-to-day experience; may have genetic and neurobiological factors similar to major depression
column4: Prevalence varies; often overlooked clinically due to milder presentation; early onset associated with worse long-term outcomes
column5: Depressed mood most of the day, more days than not, plus at least 2 of: appetite changes, sleep disturbance, low energy, low self-esteem, poor concentration, hopelessness
column6: At least 2 years in adults or 1 year in children/adolescents; symptom-free intervals no longer than 2 months; may have superimposed major depressive episodes (double depression)
column7: Major depressive disorder, adjustment disorder, personality disorder, hypothyroidism, chronic fatigue syndrome
column8: Clinical interview with careful longitudinal history; life chart or timeline helpful; assess for superimposed major depressive episodes
column9: Psychotherapy (cognitive behavioral therapy or psychodynamic therapy tailored for chronic depression); antidepressants (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors); combination therapy often needed

column2: Woman with severe mood swings, irritability, and physical symptoms in the week before menses that resolve with menstruation
column3: Dysregulation of serotonin and increased sensitivity to progesterone metabolite allopregnanolone due to luteal phase estrogen fluctuations
column4: Affects 2-5% of menstruating individuals; more severe than premenstrual syndrome which affects approximately 25%
column5: At least 5 symptoms including at least 1 affective symptom (mood lability, irritability, depressed mood, anxiety) and 1 physical symptom (breast tenderness, bloating, fatigue); symptoms peak around menses onset
column6: Symptoms occur in luteal phase (week before menses), substantially decrease or resolve week after menses; must be present in most cycles over past year
column7: Premenstrual syndrome, major depressive disorder, bipolar disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, perimenopause
column8: Daily prospective symptom ratings for at least 2 consecutive menstrual cycles using tools like Daily Record of Severity of Problems
column9: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (continuous or luteal phase dosing); combined oral contraceptives with drospirenone; cognitive behavioral therapy; lifestyle modifications

column2: Patient develops depressive symptoms within 3 months of identifiable stressor (job loss, divorce, relocation) that are out of proportion to stressor
column3: Maladaptive response to identifiable psychosocial stressor; symptoms represent distress out of proportion to severity of stressor
column4: Common diagnosis in psychiatric settings; often a working diagnosis for patients in immediate need of aid
column5: Low mood, tearfulness, feelings of hopelessness that are clinically significant but do not meet full criteria for major depressive episode
column6: Symptoms develop within 3 months of stressor onset; resolve within 6 months after stressor or its consequences terminate
column7: Major depressive disorder, normal stress response, bereavement, prolonged grief disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder
column8: Clinical interview; identify temporal relationship between stressor and symptoms; ensure symptoms do not meet criteria for another mental disorder
column9: Psychotherapy (cognitive behavioral therapy is most studied); symptom-oriented pharmacotherapy (benzodiazepines, antidepressants) may be used for severe symptoms or high suicide risk

column2: Patient with intense yearning and preoccupation with deceased person persisting beyond culturally expected timeframe after death
column3: Post-loss stress syndrome with maladaptive grief process; inability to accept permanence of loss and restore capacity for meaningful life
column4: Affects 3-10% of bereaved individuals; higher rates (up to 34%) after sudden, unexpected, or violent death or loss of child or partner
column5: Persistent intense yearning or preoccupation with deceased, intense emotional pain (sadness, guilt, anger, denial), identity disruption, avoidance of reminders, difficulty engaging in life
column6: At least 6 months post-loss (ICD-11) or 12 months (DSM-5); symptoms persist beyond culturally expected duration
column7: Normal grief, major depressive disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder, adjustment disorder
column8: Clinical interview; screening tools include Brief Grief Questionnaire (score greater than 4), Prolonged Grief-13-R (score 30 or higher), Inventory of Complicated Grief (score greater than 25)
column9: Grief-focused cognitive behavioral therapy is first-line (prolonged-grief therapy, exposure-based therapy); antidepressants not effective for grief symptoms but may help comorbid depression

column2: Young woman with unstable relationships, recurrent self-harm, fear of abandonment, and identity disturbance; "I hate you, don't leave me"
column3: Interaction between genetic factors and adverse childhood experiences (sexual/physical abuse); emotional hyperarousal vulnerability and interpersonal hypersensitivity
column4: Affects 0.7-2.7% of general adult population; 12% of outpatients and 22% of inpatients in psychiatric settings; high comorbidity with mood disorders (83%), anxiety disorders (85%), substance use (78%)
column5: Unstable self-image and relationships, affective instability, impulsivity, intense anger, chronic emptiness, suicidal behavior or self-mutilation, abandonment fears, transient paranoid ideation or dissociation
column6: Pervasive pattern beginning by early adulthood; chronic course but symptoms may improve over time with treatment
column7: Bipolar disorder, major depressive disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder, other personality disorders, substance use disorders
column8: Semi-structured interviews (Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-5, Revised Diagnostic Interview for Borderlines); requires at least 5 of 9 DSM-5 criteria
column9: Psychotherapy is treatment of choice: dialectical behavior therapy and mentalization-based therapy most effective (effect sizes 0.60-0.65); no medications approved for core symptoms; treat comorbid conditions pharmacologically

column2: Progressive ataxia with family history; "anticipation" in polyglutamine SCAs
column3: Autosomal dominant mutations causing cerebellar degeneration; polyglutamine expansions or non-polyglutamine mutations affecting cerebellar neurons and connections
column4: Rare; prevalence varies by SCA subtype and geographic region; SCA3 most common worldwide
column5: Gait and limb ataxia, dysarthria, dysdiadochokinesia, dysmetria, nystagmus, saccadic pursuit; may have pyramidal signs, peripheral neuropathy, cognitive impairment
column6: Insidious onset, slowly progressive over years to decades
column7: Friedreich ataxia, multiple system atrophy, acquired ataxias (alcohol, paraneoplastic, autoimmune), fragile X-associated tremor ataxia syndrome, other hereditary ataxias
column8: Brain MRI showing cerebellar atrophy; genetic testing for specific SCA mutations; clinical rating scales (SARA, ICARS); family history
column9: Supportive care: physical therapy, occupational therapy, speech therapy; treat specific symptoms; genetic counseling; no disease-modifying therapy currently available

column2: Cerebellar lesion with executive dysfunction, language problems, visuospatial deficits, and emotional changes
column3: Disruption of cerebellar-cerebral connectivity involving posterior cerebellar lobe (lobules VI, VIIA crus I/II, VIIB) with prefrontal, parietal, and frontotemporal cortices
column4: Occurs in various cerebellar disorders including vascular, traumatic, neoplastic, infectious, and degenerative processes
column5: Executive dysfunction (working memory, mental flexibility, abstract reasoning), impaired phonemic greater than semantic fluency, visuospatial deficits, emotional dysregulation, lack of empathy, dysphoria, depression
column6: Variable depending on underlying cause; can be present in preataxic carriers of some SCAs
column7: Frontotemporal dementia, Alzheimer disease, psychiatric disorders, other causes of cognitive impairment
column8: CCAS/Schmahmann syndrome scale; comprehensive neuropsychological testing; brain MRI; evaluation of underlying cerebellar pathology
column9: Treat underlying cerebellar disorder; cognitive rehabilitation; psychiatric support; occupational therapy; speech therapy

column2: Young-onset dementia with personality change and disinhibition; "behavioral variant" with hyperorality or hypersexuality
column3: Frontotemporal lobar degeneration with neuronal loss; proteinopathies including tau, TDP-43, or FET proteins; mutations in C9orf72, MAPT, or GRN genes
column4: Second most common young-onset dementia; onset typically before age 65; accounts for 10 to 20 percent of dementia cases
column5: Behavioral variant: disinhibition, apathy, loss of empathy, compulsive behaviors, hyperorality; Language variants: non-fluent aphasia with effortful speech or semantic dementia with loss of word meaning; relative sparing of memory and visuospatial function early
column6: Insidious onset, progressive over 5 to 10 years
column7: Alzheimer disease, Lewy body dementia, psychiatric disorders, progressive supranuclear palsy, corticobasal degeneration
column8: Clinical diagnosis using consensus criteria; neuropsychological testing showing executive, language, or social cognition deficits; brain MRI showing frontotemporal atrophy; genetic testing if family history; consider PET or CSF biomarkers
column9: Supportive care; behavioral management; speech therapy; selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors for behavioral symptoms; avoid antipsychotics; genetic counseling if familial

column2: Elderly man with visual hallucinations, parkinsonism, and fluctuating cognition; "cingulate island sign" on PET
column3: Accumulation of alpha-synuclein in Lewy bodies and Lewy neurites; often coexists with Alzheimer pathology (amyloid plaques in up to 77% of cases)
column4: Most common in men over 70-85 years; accounts for 4-6% of neurocognitive disorders
column5: Fluctuating cognition, recurrent complex visual hallucinations, spontaneous parkinsonism, rapid eye movement sleep behavior disorder, severe neuroleptic sensitivity, daytime drowsiness, prolonged staring spells, disorganized speech, autonomic dysfunction, falls, delusions, anxiety, depression
column6: Insidious onset with chronic progression; mean disease duration 5-7 years; cognitive fluctuations can resemble delirium
column7: Alzheimer disease, Parkinson disease dementia, vascular dementia, frontotemporal dementia, delirium
column8: Clinical diagnosis based on core features; MRI initially normal, progresses to diffuse atrophy; PET shows generalized hypometabolism with visual cortex involvement and "cingulate island sign"; reduced dopamine transporter uptake in basal ganglia; abnormal cardiac metaiodobenzylguanidine scintigraphy; polysomnography showing rapid eye movement sleep without atonia
column9: Cholinesterase inhibitors (rivastigmine, donepezil); memantine; avoid neuroleptics due to severe sensitivity (up to 50% have severe reactions); treat parkinsonism cautiously as levodopa response is variable; manage behavioral symptoms with non-pharmacologic approaches first

column2: Stepwise cognitive decline after stroke; history of hypertension, diabetes, or cardiovascular disease
column3: Cerebrovascular disease causing brain injury through large vessel infarcts, small vessel disease, lacunar infarcts, white matter changes, microbleeds, or strategic infarcts in critical regions (thalamus, angular gyrus, basal forebrain)
column4: Most common in men over 65 years; accounts for 14-15% of neurocognitive disorders; often coexists with Alzheimer disease (mixed dementia is common)
column5: Stepwise decline in cognition, deficits in processing speed and executive function more prominent than memory, focal neurologic signs, evidence of remote stroke on examination, symptoms starting after cerebrovascular events
column6: Stepwise progression with plateaus; onset often temporally related to cerebrovascular events; cognitive deficits persist beyond 3 months after stroke
column7: Alzheimer disease, mixed dementia, Lewy body dementia, frontotemporal dementia, normal pressure hydrocephalus
column8: Clinical history and examination showing vascular risk factors and cerebrovascular events; MRI showing leukoaraiosis, lacunar infarcts, encephalomalacia, subcortical microhemorrhages, or superficial lobar macrohemorrhages; PET showing focal hypometabolism corresponding to lesions on MRI; requires imaging evidence of cerebrovascular disease
column9: Aggressive vascular risk factor modification (control hypertension, diabetes, dyslipidemia); antiplatelet therapy or anticoagulation as appropriate; smoking cessation; exercise; cholinesterase inhibitors may provide modest benefit; address modifiable cardiovascular risk factors
